div3.head: Lost Bonds.
div3.p:
--Taken from the subscriber by the Yankees, in their raid through Amelia county in the month of May last, the following eight Confederate Registered eight per cent. Bonds, five hundred dollars each, issued August 16, 1862, and payable in January, 1881: Nos. 548, 549, 550, 552, 544, 555, 556, 557.
The foregoing Bonds were issued to me, and having been lost, as above stated, I give notice that I shall make application to the Treasury for their renewal, and the public are warned not to receive or dispose of said Bonds.

Lost, on yesterday, somewhere near the Passport-office, a Certificate of a four per cent. Bond to the amount of Eight Hundred Dollars, payable to Adolphus Cauthorn, and endorsed by him to me, and I had assigned it to — Any person finding the same will leave it with Robert W. Powers, Druggist, corner Main and Fifteenth streets. All persons are warned not to trade for such Certificate, as application has been made to the Confederate States Treasury for its renewal.

div3.head: Certificate Lost.
div3.p: --On or about the sixteenth of May last, at Drewary's Bluff, I lost a Certificate of Deposit, (No. 844,) issued by Major Taylor, at Greenville, Tennessee, to W. S. Brooks, for Five Hundred Dollars. All persons are warned, from trading for the Certificate, as I have taken measures for its renewal.

div3.head: Lost Certificate.
div3.p:
--Sometime in the month of June last I lost a Certificate of Deposit for $700, for per cent.
Confederate States Treasury Bond, issued under the act of Congress passed February 17th, 1864, made payable to Elizabeth Guthrow, and numbered 975, and issued 17th March.
All persons are warned against trading for the same, as application has been made to the Confederate States Treasury for its renewal.

Lost, at Beaver Dam station, on the Central railroad, on the 9th of May, 1864, Certificate No. 304, for two shares of the Richmond Importing and Exporting Company, one share of which was transferred to O. A. Crenshaw on the 8th January, 1864.
Also, Certificate No. 20, January 10, 1864, for five shares of the Richmond Glass Company.
New certificates will be applied for, and all persons are forewarned from trading for, or receiving, them.

div3.head: Lost or Miscarried.
div3.p: --On the 15th September, 1863, I mailed a letter directed to Street, Hungerford & Jackson, Montgomery, Alabama, containing draft No. 1,161, on warrant No. 3,644, for $4,980, drawn by R. Tyler, Register of the Confederate States Treasury, on E. C. Elmore, Treasurer, dated August 15, 1863, in favor of Messrs. Street, Hungerford & Jackson, which letter has never been received; and notice is hereby given that application will be made for a duplicate of said draft, and the public are cautioned against trading for the same.

closer.signed: Cashier Traders' Bank of the City of Richmond.

div3.p:
Lost, at Chimborazo Hospital, July 11, 1864, one Confederate Registered eight.
per cent.
Bond for $150, No. 571, issued February 9, 1863, bearing interest from the 7th day of February, 1863.
This Bond is redeemable in 1874.
I give notice that I shall make application to the Treasury for the renewal of said Bond.

Lost, the following described Certificates.
All persons are hereby warned against negotiating the same, as application has been made for their renewal: One four per cent. certificate, under act February 17, 1864, dated March 25, 1864, No. 4,857, in favor Mrs. E. S. Pinchback, for Four Hundred Dollars; one certificate, same loan, No. 4,858, dated March 25th, favor of E. F. Pinchback, for Six Hundred Dollars. Both the above signed E. C. Elmore, Treasurer Confederate States.

Stolen or Lost, a Certificate of Deposit of $200, for a Confederate four per cent. Bond, dated February 29, given to Mrs. Elizabeth Ann Nelson, and assigned to me. I intend to apply to the Treasury Department for the renewal of said Certificate, and hereby caution all persons against taking the same.

Estray or Stolen, a young Cow, black, one hind leg white and white under the belly.
A liberal reward will be paid upon her delivery to me at my store corner of Seventeenth and Baldwin streets, near Central Railroad Workshops.

div3.head: Twenty-five Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Lost, on Friday, 5th instant, on Main street, between Ninth and Eighteenth streets, a black Lace Veil, with small dots and worked border, round at the corners.
The above reward will be given to the finder if left at 41 Main street, or F. C. Brauer's Stall, No. 1, Old Market.

div3.head: Twenty-five Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Strayed from the subscriber two sow Shoats, about six months old--one nearly black, with a few white spots; the other yellow and black — no ear marks; long tails.
The above reward will be paid for their return to me at Bacon Quarter Branch.

div3.head: Stolen Horse.
div3.p:
--The stable on my farm, five miles below Richmond, on the Osborn turnpike, was broken into on Monday, the 8th instant, and a Sorrel Horse, Saddle and Bridle taken off. His two hind feet are white, with a scar on his shoulder, produced by the collar; and had no shoes on when he was taken.
I will pay a liberal price for the return of the horse, and one hundred dollars for the detection of the thief.

div3.head: Roanoke College.
div3.p:
--This institution, located at Salem, Virginia, will open its next annual session on the first of September.
Expenses graduated by the price of provisions, purchased at government rates.
For particulars enquire of the President.

div3.head: St. Mary's College, Columbia, South Carolina.
div3.p: --The exercises of this Institution will be resumed on Monday, the 5th of September proximo.

Terms: For Board and Tuition in English, Mathematics and Languages, for session of five months, $1,000, payable in advance.
No deduction will be made for absence, except in cases of sickness or expulsion.

Pupils will be supplied, with bedsteads by the college.
For particulars, apply by letter to

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--I propose to open a School for Boys, in Richmond, on the 1st of October next, and desire to rent a suitable School-Room, on Shockoe Hill.
Apply to Powers & Valentine.

div3.head: Farmville Female College.
div3.p:
--The Fall term, 1864, will begin September 28, and close on the 8th of February.
The location is safe and healthy.
The instruction will be thorough.

Terms as low as circumstances will admit.
For additional information address.
div3.closer:
A. Preot, President,
Farmville, Virginia. au 9--6t*

div3.head: Educational.
div3.p:
--I propose to resume my School, conducted on the same plan and at the same place as formerly, on the first of October next.
Patrons will please enter pupils immediately.

div3.head: Wood for Sale.
div3.p: --The subscriber, living on the Nine Mile road, three miles below Richmond, has for sale Forty Cords of Oak Wood, ready for market, which he will dispose of on reasonable terms.
Mr. R. G. Farley's interest in my business terminated, by agreement, on the 1st day of August, 1864.

div3.head: By Williamson & Co., Auctioneers,
div3.byline: (No. 192 Main street, between Ninth and Tenth.)
div3.p:
Furniture,
Fine Gold Watches,
Fancy Articles, &c.,
at Auction.

On Wednesday, the 17th August, commencing at 10 o'clock A. M., we will sell at our salesroom, No. 192 Main street, an assortment of
Furniture,
Fine Gold Watches,
Fancy Articles, &c.
The following and other articles will be offered:

list.item: Feather Beds, hair and Shuck Mattresses,

div3.p: N. B.--The Watches, some of which are very fine, will be sold at 12 o'clock precisely.
div3.closer: Williamson & Co., Auctioneers. au 13

div3.head: By Charles T. Wortham & Co., Auctioneers.
div3.p: Auction Sale.--We will sell on Wednesday, the 17th instant, commencing at 11 o'clock--

list.item: 10 barrels good to prime New Orleans Sugar,
10 boxes good to prime New Orleans Sugar,
10 tierces yellow and white Clarified Sugar,

div3.p: Salt, Sole and Upper-leather, and Groceries generally.
Consignments for this sale solicited.
div3.closer: Charles T. Wortham & Co. au 12

div3.head: By E. S. Pleasants, Auctioneer.
div3.p:
Handsome Household
Furniture,
Piano,
Gas Chandelier, &c.,
at Auction.

On Tuesday, the 16th instant, at ten o'clock, I will sell, at the residence on Franklin street, between Twenty-sixth and Twenty-seventh streets, now occupied by Dr. Tinsley, the whole of the elegant Furniture contained in said residence.
The parlors are furnished with

list.item: 1 very handsome Mahogany hair Cloth Sofa,
12 very handsome Mahogany hair Cloth Chairs,
2 very handsome Mahogany hair Cloth Rocking Chairs,

div3.p: the chambers are furnished with
in the dining-room will be found
Together with a large assortment of
Consisting of
the halls and passages are furnished with Oil Cloth throughout, Hat Rack, Mahogany Table, Cane- Seat Oak Chairs, Map, &c., &c.
the kitchen furniture comprises

together with a large quantity of useful articles not necessary to mention.
Suffice it to say, that nearly every article needed in a family may be found in this sale, and the attention of buyers is respectfully requested.

div3.head: By Hill, Dickinson & Co., Auctioneers.
div3.p: Receiver's Sale of Negroes.--In pursuance of an order of the District Court of the Confederate States for the Eastern District of Virginia, made on the 10th day of August, 1864, in the matter of L. J. Bowden, an alien enemy, dec'd, I shall sell at public auction, for cash, at the auction store of Messrs. Hill, Dickinson & Co., in the city of Richmond, on Wednesday, the 17th day of August, instant, at ten o'clock A. M., the following Slaves, to wit:
Alice Johnson, a negro woman, aged twenty-two years:
James, son of Alice, aged three years.
Cloe Green, a negro woman, aged thirty-two years.
Mary, child of Cloe, aged ten years.
Levi, child of Cloe, aged eight years.
Franklin, child of Cloe, aged six years.
Ben, child of Cloe, aged four years.
Nellie Redman, aged thirty-two years.
Delphi, child of Nellie, aged nine years.

div3.head: By D. K. Weisiger, Auctioneer.
div3.p:
One Hundred Acres of Land with small House Thereon, four miles from Richmond, on the Coal Pit Turnpike, in the county of Chesterfield, for Sale at Auction.--I will sell at auction, on Tuesday, the 16th instant, at five o'clock P. M., on the premises, the above tract of Land.
It adjoins the lands of the late Jeremiah Hobbs and Mrs. Anderson.
This place is well adapted for a market farm.
On it is a well that, in former days, furnished the best water in the neighborhood, but now needs attention.
The nearness of this land to the city should induce persons desiring to invest to attend.
Terms: One-half cash; balance to suit purchaser.
div3.closer:
D. K. Weisiger,
Auctioneer.s au 4

div3.p: After the sale of the Land, forty of fifty cords of Wood, on the premises.

div3.head: By P. W. Grubbs, Auctioneer.
div3.p:
House and Lot near the Corner of Clay and Fifteenth streets for Sale at Auction.--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Tuesday, the 16th August, 1864, at half-past 4 o'clock P. M., a comfortable tenement, located as above, owned by James Conway, and occupied by punctual tenants at thirty-five dollars per month.
It has four rooms.--There is a well of water in the yard.
Terms: Cash.
div3.closer:
P. W. Grubbs, Auctioneer,
Successor to Goddin & Apperson. au 11

div3.head: House and Lot on West Mill street, near the Central Railroad shops, for Sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--Immediately after the sale of the above property, say at 5 o'clock P. M., will be sold at auction, on the premises, the House and Lot located as above.
It has a front of forty feet on West Mill street, and a depth of two hundred feet.
Terms: Cash or credit, at the option of the purchaser.
div3.closer:
P. W. Grubbs. Auctioneer.
Successor to Goddin & Apperson. au 13

div3.head: By H. Benson & Brother, Auctioneers.
div3.p:
A Beautiful Farm in Albemarle county for Rent and Negroes for Hire.--Being unable to give my personal attention to my Farm, I will rent it and hire the negroes to a good tenant, If not rented privately beforehand, I will put it up at public auction on the 1st day of September, 1864; on which day I will also sell the growing crop, horses, cattle, hogs and farming utensils.
Farm contains three hundred and sixty-eight acres, and lies six (6) miles north of Charlottesville.
div3.closer:
F. E. G. Carr,
Charlottesville, Virginia. au 8--eod2w

div3.head:
Neva.
Stearine Candles.
div3.p: --A small lot of the above superior Candles just received.
Pure Wines and Liquors, for Medicinal purposes.

list.item: P. Hanger's Whiskey, warranted four years old;

div3.p: Received and for sale by
div3.closer:
L. Yerby,
No. 5, Twelfth street, south of Main. au 15--eod3t*

list.head: Also,
list.item: A great variety of Trimmings and Notions.

div3.head: By Redwood, Phillips & Co., Auctioneers.
div3.p:
We will sell at our Store, Monday, 15th instant, at 10 o'clock, a general assortment of
Furniture,
Clothing and Shoes,
Stoves, Tobacco,
Cigars, Watches, &c.
div3.closer:
Redwood, Phillips & Co.,
Auctioneers. au 13

div3.head: By James M. Taylor, Auctioneer.
div3.p:
Two houses and Lots, on St.
Stephen's street, for Sale at Auction.--Will be sold on Monday, the 15th day of August, at four and a half o'clock P. M., on the promises, two Tenements on St.
Stephen's street--one a Brick Tenement, two stories above basement, with five rooms, and at present occupied by Mr. E. Corbin.
The Lot fronts sixty feet and runs back one hundred and twenty feet. The other Tenement is a frame building, with three rooms, suitable for a grocery store and dwelling.
Terms: Made to suit the purchaser.
div3.closer: James M. Taylor, Auctioneer. au 12--3t

div3.head: By P. W. Grubbs, Auctioneer.
div3.p:
Very valuable Residence on Second, between Marshall and Clay streets, for Sale at Auction. --Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Monday, August the 15th, at 4½ o'clock P. M., that very desirable Residence, located as above, now in the occupancy of Mr. William S. Roganni.
It has seven rooms, besides kitchen; has gas and water; and having been built within a few years, is in a most excellent condition; indeed, it is a very desirable residence.
The location of the property is good and the neighborhood a very excellent one.

Terms: One-third cash, balance at six and twelve months, or all cash, at the option of the purchaser.
Possession will be given in fifteen days.
div3.closer:
P. W. Grubbs, Auctioneer,
Successor to Goddin & Apperson. au 10

div3.head: By E. S. Pleasants, Auctioneer.
div3.p:
Parlor, Chamber and Dining-Room Furniture, &c., at Auction.--On Monday, the 15th instant, commencing at ten o'clock A. M., I will sell at the residence situated on Third street, between Grace and Franklin, a large and excellent assortment of
Parlor,
Chamber and
Dining-room
Furniture.
In the parlor will be found:
in the chambers may be seen:
Also,
a large variety of
will be found in the Dining-Room the usual variety of Crockery and Glassware; amongst
Also,

list.item: 1 splendid Cooking Stove, (in order), with all its paraphernalia,

div3.p: And many other useful and very desirable things too numerous to mention.
The public generally are invited to attend this sale.
div3.closer: E. S. Pleasants, Auctioneer. au 11

div3.head: By P. W. Grubbs, Auctioneer.
div3.p:
Large Brick Tenement on the South side of Marshall, between Jefferson and Madison streets, for Sale at Auction.--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Monday, August the 15th, at five o'clock P. M., that very valuable large Brick Tenement, located as above, formerly occupied by the late Robert A. Glazebrook, now renting for eighteen hundred dollars per annum, payable monthly, with the right of possession on the fourth of January next.
The house has eleven rooms, including those in the basement and garret, besides kitchen and water in the yard.
The lot is large and very valuable.
It has a front of sixty-five feet on Marshall street and a depth of one hundred and fifty-five feet to a wide alley.
div3.closer:
P. W. Grubbs, Auctioneer,
Successor to Goddin & Apperson.s au 11

div3.head: Very valuable Lot, at the Corner of Clay and Foushee streets, immediately opposite the Residence of Adolph Dill, Esq., for Sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--Immediately after the sale of the above property, say at 5½ o'clock, will be sold at auction, on the premises, the lot located as above, fronting thirty feet on Clay street, running back one hundred and forty feet to an alley.
This is exceedingly valuable property.
Terms: Cash or credit, at the option of the purchaser.
div3.closer:
P. W. Grubbs, Auctioneer,
Successor to Goddin & Apperson. au 12

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --Delinquent consumers of Gas in Jefferson Ward are hereby notified that if they fail to pay their gas bills before the hour of 3 o'clock P. M. To-day they will be dealt with according to the requirements of the following extract from the ordinance concerning the Gas Works:

By an ordinance passed by the Council, May 6th, 1858, if any bill remain unpaid for ten days next after that on which it is presented, the Auditor shall notify the Superintendent, who shall stop the gas from being used on the premises in respect to which the default exists, and if not paid within fifteen days, five per centum will be added to the original amount of the bill, and it shall be placed in the hands of the City Collector.
div3.closer:
P. W. Ralston, for
T. B. Harrison, Auditor. au 15--1t

div3.head: Preserving sugar,

list.head: Wines and Liquors.
list.item: 200 bottles pure Old Madeira, late Judge Stanard's importation,
200 bottles pure Old Sherry, late Judge Stanard's importation,
Stuart's Whiskey, Hanger's Whiskey, Blackberry Brandy, &c.

div3.p: These are believed to be the only pure Wines and Liquors on sale in this city.
For sale by
div3.closer:
L. Yerby,
No. 5 south Twelfth street. au 9--eod1w*

div3.head: Coffee, sugar and Molasses.
div3.closer:
Robert Hough & Co.,
No. 14 Pearl street. au 15--6t*

div3.head: Sundries.
div3.p: For sale by
on Sale, superior Manufactured Tobacco, of the following desirable brands:
The above is all old Tobacco, in perfect order, and unsurpassed by anything in this market.
div3.closer:
Mitchell & Tyler,
108 Main street. au 11--6t

div3.head: On consignment,
div3.closer:
D. S. Huffard & Co.,
Thirteenth and Governor streets. au 11--1w

div3.head: Crushed sugar,

list.item: young Hyson Tea, a fine article,

div3.p: For sale by
div3.closer:
S. C. Greenhow,
Thirteenth street, between Main and Cary. au 12--3t

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --Always on hand, and for sale, Molasses Barrels, Liquor Barrels, Flour Barrels and Kegs of all kinds and sizes; Buckets, Tues, &c. Orders can be left at H Delarne's Grocery, No. 7 Franklin street, or at my Cooper shop, on Seventeenth street, corner of Baldwin, near the Central Railroad Workshops Delivered anywhere in the city gratis.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--The boat Clara will leave for Buchanan on Monday, August 15th, at 4 o'clock, P. M., and will receive freight for all intermediate points on the Canal until it leaves.
Freight sent by this boat will reach its destination sooner than by the usual freight boats.
Apply on board, at Basin Shed.
div3.closer: J. L. Waldrop & Co. au 13--2t*

div3.head: No. 1 Blacksmith for Sale.
div3.p:
--We have at private sale a No. 1 Blacksmith and Horse-Shoer, about thirty-one years of age, and sold for no fault.
His equal can seldom be found.
div3.closer: Hill, Dickinson & Co. au 12--3t

div3.p:
Real Estate for Sale, five miles from the Town of Greensboro, North Carolina, and three Quarters of A Mile from New Garden College, Situated on the road Leading from Greensboro to Salem.--The improvements are a two-story dwelling, nearly , built in 1800, has eight good rooms, all well finished.
The house is painted white, and believed to be one of the best houses in the county.
The out-buildings are two excellent houses for servants, with brick chimneys; a good smoke-house; a very superior and commodious barn, built after the style of those in Pennsylvania, will accommodate twelve horses; a corn-crib, built of logs.
Has a well of water not to be surpassed in any State.
The land attached its. Two Hundred and Twenty-one acres, only about one-third cleared, the rest in original growth of oak and chestnut.
On the place and near the house is an orchard of one thousand fruit trees, of three years growth, of the choicest selection of Peach, Apricot and Apple.
This place possesses the additional attraction of being located in one of the healthiest portions of the State, and in five miles of the nation of the Danville railroad, at Greensboro'. --The owner, wishing to purchase city property, will sell the place for forty thousand dollars, new issue, or twenty-five hundred dollars in gold.
Address "Box 86," Raleigh, North Carolina.

div3.head: A Farm, with the Stock, Crops, Farming Utensils, &c., for Sale.
div3.p:
--The subscriber is authorized to sell, privately, a Farm in Powhatan county, together with all of the Stock, Crops, Farming Utensils, &c., thereon.
The Farm contains three hundred and fourteen acres, and is situated on the Buckingham road, about twenty-two miles from Richmond and four miles from Powhatan Station, Richmond and Danville railroad, in a healthy locality, and well supplied with good well and branch water.
The land is of fair quality about one-half or two-thirds arable, the balance in pine and oak growth.
The buildings consist of a two-story Dwelling-House, (lately fitted up), with four rooms and passage, besides a basement and all necessary out-houses.
The Stock--one Horse and three Mules, yoke of Oxen, five head of cattle and fourteen hogs.
The Farming Utensils are nearly new, and embrace the following: Wagons, Carts, Thrashing-Machine, Wheat Fan, Corn-Sheller, Cutting-Knives, Scythes and Ploughs of all kinds.
The Crops — Wheat, Oats, Corn, Peas, Potatoes, Sorghum, &c.; and, if desired, the on the place will be hired for the balance of the year, Mr. E. M. Farley, the Manager, will show the land, crops, &c., to any one wishing to the farm.

Terms: Cash, and possession given immediately.
For further particulars address J. B. Goode,
Genito Post-office, Powhatan county, Virginia.

div3.head: Five Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from Howard's Grove Hospital, on the 6th instant, my boy Thornton; of black color and eighteen years old; about five feet eight inches high; rather thick lips, and rough featured; his front under teeth spread out like there was a tooth out. He was raised by William Tolliver, in Hanover county, near Hawes's Shop.
I will give the above reward for his apprehension, so I get him, or delivered to me at Robert Lumpkin's in Richmond.

div3.head: Two Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p: --Run away, on the 7th of August, my man Tom; he is about five feet eight inches high; stout built; black; fifty-five or sixty years old.--Bought about a year ago from Warren county, North Carolina--sold by Mrs. Mason, administratrix.--The above reward will be paid if lodged in jail so as I can get him.
div3.closer:
James Smith,
On Nine Mile road, five miles east of Richmond. au 15--6t*

div3.head: One Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Released from the jail in the county of Charlotte, by the Yankee raiders, on the 25th of June, my man Claiborne; and when last heard from was going in the direction of Reams' Station.
Claiborne is a mulatto, about five feet high, well set, smiles when spoken to; the only mark or scar recollected is on one of his legs, occasioned by an oxcart wheel having run over it, leaving a bad scar.--I will pay the above reward for the delivery of said negro to me, or secured in any way so I can get him. Address.

div3.head: Five Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away, on Monday, August 1, a negro boy, named Henry, the property of Joseph G. Mettert.
He is about twenty-three years old, five feet eight or nine inches high, quick spoken, spare built, black complexion, and speaks German well.
The above reward will be paid for his delivery to
div3.closer:
William K. Sledd,
At Confederate State Police Depot. au 11--6t*

div3.head: Four Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from my farm, on the night of the 6th instant, my man Joshua.
He is about thirty-five years of age, well built, full whisker; had on a pair of new brogues and new shut, with blue stripe on the collar.
1 bought him of & Bowman on the 27th of July.
I will give be above reward if left at their jail, in Richmond.,

div3.head: Five Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from the Richmond Arsenal, where he was hired, about the 20th of July, my negro man, Peter miles, sometimes called Peter Redd.
He is twenty-two or twenty-three years of age, five feet eight or nine inches high, gingerbread color, rather a long face, nose rather long and flat, and carries himself very erect.
When he left the arsenal he wore a grey jacket and cap. He is no doubt making an effort to pass through our lines.
I will give the above reward if caught beyond the limits of the city, or two hundred and fifty dollars if caught within the corporate limits and secured in any jail so that I get him.

div3.head: Four thousand five Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p: --I will pay four thousand five hundred dollars for the apprehension and delivery to me in Richmond, or for securing them so that I get them, the following Slaves, to wit:
Jordan, a yellow man, about twenty-seven years old, a tolerable carpenter and blacksmith. --Was raised near Christiansburg, Virginia.
Lewis, a black man, thirty years old; purchased of T. L. Drewney or Broddle, near Hendersonville, North Carolina.
Joshua, black, about twenty-eight years old; raised by Walter Coles, of Pittsylvania county; has rather a down look, and is very stout.
Jack, about eighteen years old, black and slim; bought of P. J. Stern, of Raleigh, North Carolina.
Jim, black, about twenty-one or twenty-two years old; raised in Maryland; is tall and very likely.
William, a brown-skin boy, about twenty or twenty-two years old; raised in or near this city; once owned by F. J. Sampson, an agent at the Richmond and Danville depot.

Elijah, of brown complexion, about thirty-five years old; raised near Charlottesville, and is a No. 1 cook.
Both of his legs were swollen and sore at the time he left.
Sally, a mulatto girl, about twenty-five years old; raised in Loudoun county; was purchased of N. M. Lee; tall and slender, with long black hair.
Harriet, fifteen or sixteen years old, brown skin, with a bushy head of hair.

They left my farm, in Lunenburg, about the last of June, with the Wilson raiding party.
I will pay the above reward for all of them, or five hundred dollars for any one of them.

One Hundred Dollars reward will be paid for the delivery of my boy Andrew, who left me at the Danville depot on the morning of the 30th of July.
He is black, about fourteen years of age; has a small white over his left eye about the size of a ten cent .--Andrew was raised in Petersburg, where he may attempt to go. The above reward will be paid by Messrs. S. N. Davis & Co. if the boy is left with them, or secured in jail so that I get him.
div3.closer:
S. E. Edmonds,
News Ferry, Halifax county, Virginia. au 4--ts

div3.head: One Hundred and fifty Dollars reward for my man Joe.
div3.p:
--He is about twenty-three years old, five feet six or seven inches high, gingerbread color, looks down when spoken to. He carried away blue pants and gray frock coat.
He generally wears a round jacket and home-made pants.
I will give the above reward of delivered to James Kersey, in Richmond, or secured in any jail so I get him.

div3.head: Five Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from the subscriber, about the first of February last, boy John, about fourteen or fifteen years old, light copper color, with short, straight hair; had on when be left a new suit of cotton clothes, dyes snuff color.
John was purchased of Dr. Wright, of Alabama.
I have no doubt he is with our army.
The above reward will be paid for his apprehension and delivery to Lee & Bowman, Richmond, Virginia, or secured in any jail so that I get him.

div3.head: Dissolution.
div3.p:
--The concern of Arents, Norfleet & Co, is this day dissolved by the sale of Mr. Arents's interest to Mr. D. T. Williams.
All parties indebted to, of holding claims against, the concern will call on either party for settlement, for which purpose only the name of the concern will be used.
div3.closer:
George Arents,
Hill & Norfleet.
Richmond, August 4th, 1864.

div3.head: New concern.
div3.p:
--The undersigned have the day formed a co-partnership, under the firm and style of Williams & Norfleet, for the purpose of conducting a General Auction and Commission Business, and have taken the large and commodious warehouse on the corner of Main and Thirteenth streets. We shall be constantly supplied with the most choice brands of Chewing and Smoking Tobacco, Cotton Yarns, Domestic and Woolen Goods direct from manufacturers of established repentance.
Also, all classes of goods now to be had. may rest assured of prompt and especial to their interests.
Liberal advances will be made all consignments in hand.
Consignments of country produce will also be attended to and prompt returns made.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --Having, in accordance with the above announcement, retired from the auction and commission business, I return my thanks to my friends and the public for the liberal patronage extended to me in my business connections heretofore in the city, and respectfully ask a continuance of their favors to the new concern of Messrs. Williams & Norfleet, Richmond, Va.
